Landau’s Fermi Liquid Theory

  • Curiously, independent-particle models describe some many-Fermion metallic systems even when their inter-particle interactions are very strong. These are “Normal Fermi Liquids”.
    • For example, at low temperature, the heat capacity of 3He^3He3He﻿ is linear with a gradient determined by an enhanced particle mass that depends on the density; the same behaviour as with the independent-particle model.

Normal Fermi Liquids

  • Consider a system of non-interacting Fermions with single-particle states ψ1,…ψ∞\psi_1, \dots\psi_\inftyψ1​,…ψ∞​﻿, giving many-particle (Slater determinant) states.
    • Here, {i1,…,iN}\{i_1,\dots,i_N\}{i1​,…,iN​}﻿ are the quantum numbers of the occupied single-particle states.
  • Labelling many-particle states by occupation numbers of single-particle states gives (where ni=0,1n_i=0,1ni​=0,1﻿ is the occupation number of state iii﻿),
  • Assuming no phase transition occurs, taking a non-interacting many-particle state and switching on the inter-particle interactions produces a state representing many interacting particles. If the same is also true in reverse, then there is a one-to-one correspondence, ie the properties of ∣ψi1,…,iN>\left|\psi_{i_1,\dots,i_N}\right>∣ψi1​,…,iN​​⟩﻿ determine those of ∣ψ>\left|\psi\right>∣ψ⟩﻿.
    • Hence, an interacting system ∣ψ>\left|\psi\right>∣ψ⟩﻿ is defined by the same occupation numbers;
    • Fermi systems exhibiting this one-to-one correspondence are normal Fermi liquids.

Quasiparticles

  • If the ground-state of a many-Fermion system is ∣n1,…,np,…,n∞>\left|n_1,\dots,n_p,\dots,n_\infty\right>∣n1​,…,np​,…,n∞​⟩﻿, then ∣n1,…,np+1,…,n∞>\left|n_1,\dots,n_p+1,\dots,n_\infty\right>∣n1​,…,np​+1,…,n∞​⟩﻿ in a non-interacting system represents adding a single particle to state p⃗\vec pp​﻿, whereas in an interacting system it represents adding a quasiparticle to state p⃗\vec pp​﻿.
    • A quasiparticle is a bare particle, together with the distortion it causes to the fermion distribution as interactions are slowly turned on.
    • Where E0E_0E0​﻿ is ground-state energy, the energy of the interacting many-particle system is E0+ϵλ(p⃗)E_0+\epsilon_\lambda(\vec p)E0​+ϵλ​(p​)﻿, defining the quasiparticle energy ϵλ(p⃗)\epsilon_\lambda(\vec p)ϵλ​(p​)﻿.
  • For a filled Fermi sphere of non-interacting particles and one extra particle of momentum p⃗\vec pp​﻿, where p>pFp>p_Fp>pF​﻿, ∣p−pF∣≪pF|p-p_F|\ll p_F∣p−pF​∣≪pF​﻿ and vF=pfmv_F=\frac{p_f}{m}vF​=mpf​​﻿,
    • Turning on the interaction, total momentum is conserved, and the extra particle evolves into a quasiparticle of momentum p⃗\vec pp​﻿.
      • Given the one-to-one relationship in the states, we expect the quasiparticle excitation energy ϵλ(p⃗)−μ\epsilon_\lambda(\vec p)-\muϵλ​(p​)−μ﻿ to have the same p⃗\vec pp​﻿ dependence as the non-interacting system, but modified by a scaling factor.
      • This scaling is provided by the effective mass m∗m^*m∗﻿ (qualitatively different from the band effective mass).
      • Quasiparticle excitation energy is therefore
        • Here, vF=pFm∗v_F=\frac{p_F}{m^*}vF​=m∗pF​​﻿ is the quasiparticle group velocity on the Fermi surface.
  • In anisotropic systems, m∗m^*m∗﻿ is quite artificial, and it can be more useful to use the quasiparticle density of states, which at low temperatures, dictates all physical properties;

Landau Fermi Liquid Theory

  • Turning on the interaction adiabatically, we obtain an eigenstate of the real system where nλ(p⃗)n_\lambda(\vec p)nλ​(p​)﻿ represents the distribution of quasiparticles.
  • The level of excitation in the system is defined by the quasiparticle excitation distribution
    • Here, nλ0(p⃗)=n(0)(ϵλ(p⃗)−μ)n_\lambda^0(\vec p)=n^{(0)}(\epsilon_\lambda(\vec p)-\mu)nλ0​(p​)=n(0)(ϵλ​(p​)−μ)﻿ is the ground-state distribution function and n(0)(x)n^{(0)}(x)n(0)(x)﻿ is a step function in xxx﻿.
    • At low temperatures, quasiparticles and quasiholes are excited near the Fermi surface.
  • Fermi liquid theory assumes that the system is in contact with a reservoir with chemical potential μ\muμ﻿, allowing NNN﻿ to deviate from the ground-state value.
  • The free energy F=U−μNF=U-\mu NF=U−μN﻿ is used to allow the formalism to be framed in terms of excitations from the ground state. It may be approximated well below the Fermi temperature TF=EF/kBT_F=E_F/k_BTF​=EF​/kB​﻿ by a taylor expansion in δnλ(p⃗)\delta n_\lambda(\vec p)δnλ​(p​)﻿;

Second Quantisation - Fermions

  • Second quantisation provides a short hand notation to write the Hamiltonian for many-particle systems, allowing understanding non-Fermi Liquid behaviour.
  • Again, writing many-particle Slater determinant states of a non-interacting system where ni=0,1n_i=0,1ni​=0,1﻿ is the occupation nuber of state iii﻿ as
    • The general wavefunction for an interacting many-electron system can be written as a linear combination of these Slater determinant states;q

    • These can all be derived using the anti-commutation rules {ci,cj†}=δi,j\{c_i,c_j^\dagger\}=\delta_{i,j}{ci​,cj†​}=δi,j​﻿ and {ci,cj}={ci†,cj†}=0\{c_i,c_j\}=\{c_i^\dagger,c_j^\dagger\}=0{ci​,cj​}={ci†​,cj†​}=0﻿ with {a,b}≡ab+ba\{a,b\}\equiv ab+ba{a,b}≡ab+ba﻿.
